characters: ALMOST SIMULTANEOUS DIALOGUE FOLLOWS. IT BUILDS UNTIL IT
DUPLICATE THE SOUND OF LOUD AND BAWDY SEX.
BACK TO AARON AS WE SUPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A restaurant supply truck is curbside, near a small  restaurant.  GERALD GRUNICK, forty-one, is closing the ba door of his truck, feeling good about the world, a common state for him.  He moves towards the cab of the truck and inside as we SUPER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he sits down beaming over his recent good fortune... n REVEAL his twelve-year-old son, TOM, seated quietly besid He seems a bit down.  Gerald glances at his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know a recent Saturday I've sold more.  You didn't think I'd sell that health restaurant, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Not even you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why so glum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nothing.  I've got a problem, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you bothering by those waitresses making a fuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But, honest.  What are you supposed to say when they keep talking about your looks?  I don't even know what they mean -- "Beat them off with a stick." Gerald stiffs a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Tom, I feel a little proud when people comment on your looks.  Maybe you should feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Proud?  I'm just embarrassed that I like when they say those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as that's your only problem you're...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not. He looks directly at his father and talks quietly, and si

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got my report card.  Three Cs, two Ds and an incomplete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my.  I see you studying so hard, Tom.  What do you think the problem is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just have to try harder.  I don't  know.  I will. (talking himself into it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.  I will.  I will. He shakes his head for emphasis, glad he's received this talk from himself -- he hands the card to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Dad, this talk helped.  Will  you sign it, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he signs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it help if I got you a tutor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly hopeful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be great. (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better help.  What can you do with yourself if all you do is look good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AARON ALTMAN, looking almost preposterously young in his graduation gown -- is delivering his valedictory.  He is rare bread -- a battle-scarred innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and finally to the teachers of Whitman High School, I don't have the words to express my gratitude which may have more to say about the quality  of the English Department here than  my own limitations... He awaits a laugh and gets only the weird sound of collec discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that was, of course, not meant to be taken seriously.  A personal note.   I am frequently asked what the special  difficulties are in being graduated  from High School two months shy of my  fifteenth birthday.  I sometimes  think it was the difficulties  themselves which enabled me to do it. If I'd been appreciated or even tolerated I wouldn't have been in such a hurry to graduate.  I hope the next student who comes along and is able to excel isn't made to feel so much an outcast.  But I'm looking forward to college; this is the happiest day I've had in a long time.  I thank you and I forgive you. This is very little applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always so confused by Aaron. Is he brave and earnest or just a conceited little dick-head?

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: As Aaron walks to his seat past three full grown tough lo semi-literate high school graduates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clusters of graduates at the fence bordering the sunken s yard looking down as the tough cap and gowners seen earli cuff Aaron around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron feeling from a blow -- his lip bleeding -- his teet covered with blood...as he gets to his feet.  He is livid something primal triggered by this brutality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Stephen -- take your last licks. (points at his face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this will heal -- what I'm going to say to you will scar you forever.  Ready?  Here it is. He dodges as they come after him.  They catch him by the and hurl him to the ground.  As he gets up he hurls his devastating verbal blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never make more than nineteen thousand dollars a year. Ha ha ha. They twist his arm and grip him -- his face scraped on th concrete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, take this:  You'll never leave South Boston and I'm going to see the whole damn world.  You'll never know the pleasure of writing a graceful sentence or having an original thought.  Think about it. He's punched in the stomach and sinks to the ground.  As Young Toughs walk off Aaron catches a phrase of their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen thousand dollars... Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE CRAIG, ten years old, is in her room typing.  Above desk where she works is a bulletin board with letters and pictures tacked to each one.  Her desk has several file r which contain bulging but neat stacks of air mail envelop a roll of stamps in a dispenser is to one side.  Jane typ very well in the glare of her desk lamp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over; as she types)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Felatzia, it's truly amazing to me that we live a world apart and yet have the same favorite music. I loved the picture you sent and have it up on my bulletin board. You're growing so much faster than I am that I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOWING Jane's FATHER standing near the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...am starting to get jealous. I read in the newspapers about the Italian strike and riots in Milan.  I hope you weren't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey?... Jane SCREAMS, and grabs her heart, breathing heavily, bab nervously at her Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God -- Daddy -- don't...don't... don't ever scare me like that -- please. We SUPER:  "FUTURE NETWORK NEWS PRODUCER" Her father is himself taken aback with the shock of her r Falling back towards the door:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane -- For God's sake... (recovering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's time for you to go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have two more pen pals and then I'm done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to finish tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he doesn't get in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooo.  This way the rotation stays the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish quickly.  I don't want you getting obsessive about these  things.  Good night. We REMAIN WITH Jane who has obviously become disconcerted troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jane moves to room at the other end of the hall -- a f room where her Father reads the latest Rolling Stone of t mid-60's -- Hunter Thompson, the New Journalism, the slim Jann Wenner -- Jane bursts into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, you want me to choose my words so carefully and then you just throw a word like 'obsessive' at me.  Now, unless I'm wrong and... (enunciating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...please correct me if I am, 'obsession' is practically a psychiatric term... concerning people who don't have anything else but the object of their obsession -- who can't stop and do anything else.  Well, Here I am stopping to tell you this.  Okay? So would you please try and be a little more precise instead of calling a person something like 'obsessive.' She advances furiously on her Father since even this stru even with two additional pen pal letters to get off, she enough sense of duty to kiss him good night before stormi the room.  She exits the room INTO BLACK. Stay on BLACK as we begin MAIN TITLES:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerging from the blackness -- Jane Craig -- now a twenty-eight-year-old woman -- a long speed walker wearin jacket to which reflecting stripes have been glued -- the of gear only possessed by someone who runs at off-hours. Jacket itself is a wish-I-had-it souvenir from some impor news assignment, the sort of treasure you love about all yet never mention.  She stops running as she feeds quarte the first of a phalanx of newspaper machines -- getting s different papers before moving on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she enters from the bathroom, having showered and dres The sun is jus now rising.  She sits next to her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Filofax book is almost an additional character -- a c hand-fashioned tool of Jane's trade.  She flicks at a pag takes down a typewritten sheet scotch-taped to it showing room number of her crew and reporter.

dialogues.speaker: ON JANE
dialogues.text: As she dials one room number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi...It's me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON CAMERAMAN -- his equipment in evidence though essentially asleep holding his bedmate's hand, as he list to Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's thirty minutes before you have to meet me in the lobby -- nudge your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's probably no time to eat... but there's a cafeteria at the bus depot once we get down there.  I love working with you two...It  saves me a call. She dales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Aaron is switching his TV from station to station, monitoring the early morning news.  His PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  Turn on your TV... Good Morning America, the Morning News and Today are all about to talk to Arnold  Schwarzenegger and I think he's  live on at least two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At six o'clock on the wake-up news they used the wrong missile graphic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Austrian accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen, Arnold just said that he's been making three million a movie now.  But he's not ever  gonna change.  He's still the same person when he was making two  million dollars a movie.  He feels no different.  He also bought a brand- new condo with Maria, they gonna furnish tastefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half hour in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Austrian accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll see you in the lobbies [sic]. She hangs up -- takes the phone off the hook and lays it bed for a moment's solitude.  She sits stiffly, palms on her legs.  It looks like someone with unusually good post waiting for something, and now we BEGIN TO SEE the first redden and she begins to cry.  Now she sobs -- then mirac shakes it off and exits quickly to the bathroom.  This cr episode is clearly part of her morning routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane standing behind her husband-wife - camera-sound team as they train their attention on Aaron; who is getting re do a stand-up.  There is a DERELICT off to one side.  Aar his microphone at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hair's a little funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an ethnic curl, I can't do anything about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of a little -- it's a bit... You want a mirror?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- Don't worry about it.  Let's do this. Jane nods her assent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other times, for other purposes, there might be a band and bunting here at the bus depot for J.D. Singer's return from war.  He...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  But look at how wonderful his face is. She points to the derelict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean use him...That's nice.  Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put him in the low corner of the frame -- good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other times, with other purposes, there might be a band and bunting here at the bus depot for J.D. Singer's return from war.  Last week he was decorated by a president for heroism in a war.  But it was the civil war -- in Angola -- and he was in it for the money. He puts the microphone down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. He passes a vending machine and checks the stray hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane in the distant b.g. on the phone.  Aaron and crew sh as the bus pulls up, hisses to a stop and tired, rumpled passengers exit the bus.  J.D. SINGER, strong, 9'6" figur emerges and is displeased to find a camera trained on him He reacts with all the grace of a short mercenary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go 'way. J.D. gets his luggage from the compartment under the bus. crew shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He starts walking -- the four person newsteam staying wit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We came from Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding out microphone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has it been since you've been home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.  Fuck.  Fuck.  Fuckes.  Snot... Fuckee.  You want to use that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on how big a news day it  is. They reach Jane.  She calls to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.D.  I'm Jane Craig.  I spoke to you in Angola.  I gave you some sugarless gum and Handi-Wipes. As he reacts to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane sitting next to Aaron making detailed timing notes a screens the material shot that day on a portable monitor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's where I asked him about being scared? (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should work on your speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It makes me nervous to think about it.  Let's do this. She consults her notes and goes back to the exact spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this business of war -- do you get scared?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on tape; he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little freaked right now about seeing my father though. He laughs self-consciously and turns briefly away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that turn away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is at the lectern in the darkened auditorium as two monitors display some taped news pieces she has assembled the lectern is a sign telling us we are at the Conference Local Television News Broadcasters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in darkness)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a point I'm trying to make about these pieces coming up. A WOMAN'S OUTLINE blacked out from behind -- her VOICE ELECTRICALLY DISGUISED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.; angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think any client of mine makes less than fifty thousand dollars a year which means they can afford the best and you're damn right I feel good that that includes me.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER WOMAN
dialogues.text: in blackness, her VOICE DISGUISED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You'd be surprised at who a working girl meets.  I've been a working girl for what? -- over a year anyway and that must be a thousand men and I don't think there's an age or type that hasn't been in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Policemen?  -- Doctor? -- Lawyer...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure.  Television reporters. A laugh from the audience.  There is a:

dialogues.speaker: FULL FIGURE
dialogues.text: A WOMAN in blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seventeen now and I've been working the streets for two years and I guess to be honest -- I stopped thinking of it as temporary. The lights come up on the room.  The two screens go black there is general APPLAUSE.  Jane blinks nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't applaud.

dialogues.speaker: ON AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: Sitting in groups of three -- NEWS TEAM from around the c remarkably similar in comparison...a great looking woman, looking man (either young or attractively avuncular) and or Hispanic.  They still APPLAUD -- not yet having graspe sincerity of Jane's plea which she presses with more urge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  Don't!! (she yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gathered these pieces as an example of what's WRONG with local television news. The applause stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The excerpts from THREE SEPARATE SERIES on prostitution were SIMULTANEOUSLY broadcast by all stations in one city during sweeps week.  By what bend of either or suspension of duty is that broadcast news? She pauses half a beat for possible applause -- hearing n she continues.  An anchorman sneezes -- four people shout "gesundheit" simultaneously -- they laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The legacy of Edward R. Murrow, Eric Sevareid, William Shirer, David Brinkley and Walter Cronkite is being squandered in a desperate popularity contest.  Our profession is in danger:

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: As Jane continues, REVEALING that the news team now have more in common.  They do not like Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday's compliment has somehow managed to become today's kiss of death.  To be considered a serious journalist is no longer flattering. It presents the risk of being labeled ponderous, or worse yet, elitest,  right?

dialogues.speaker: SHOT CONTINUES
dialogues.text: Women playing with their hair, young man bored...one middle-aged anchorman fusses with a spot on his tie...

dialogues.speaker: ON JANE
dialogues.text: Briefly departing from text.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of you know what I'm talking about.   We're all trying to act together than  we are.  But we care.  So, we're all  secretly terrified, aren't we? Not a peep -- she is thrown but doggedly presses on with prepared speech though her throat constricts a bit, her v begins to rasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are being increasingly influenced by the star system.  The network anchormen are so powerful they  compromise our last best hope.  The  current group is clearly qualified,  tied still to our best traditions, but  who follows these men?

dialogues.speaker: SHOT MOVES TO TOM GRUNICK
dialogues.text: Seated with other members of his news team, a young blond woman whose hand is resting on his inner leg, a good look Hispanic.  Tom feels a growing excitement -- Jane is not a speaker, she seems a savior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. His female colleague looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've known so many women like that.  They don't like their looks so they're angry.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO JANE
dialogues.text: Fumbling with her cards, sunk but game -- gamer than she wish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to talk about other trends but... (mumbling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the magazine shows, news at profit, influence of Entertainment Tonight, the danger, the hope, the dream, the question...Oh, I was going to show you a tape -- a story that was carried by all networks on the same night -- the same night -- not one network noted a major policy change in Salt Two nuclear disarmament talks... Here's what they ran instead...Go ahead.  Show the tape.

dialogues.speaker: ON MONITORS
dialogues.text: Showing the Japanese Domino Championships as broadcast by networks in the Spring of 1985.  It is quite spectacular dominoes falling into one another provoking waves, crossi bridges, setting off little fireworks.  JANE'S AUDIENCE a loudly and squeals with delight.

dialogues.speaker: ON SCENE
dialogues.text: Jane between the two monitors.  She begins to speak loudl the AUDIENCE NOISES of approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's good film.  I know it's fun.  I like fun.  It's just not news. (as they continue to applaud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're lucky you love it -- you're going to get a lot more just like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane sitting rocked into momentary catatonia, by the even Dazed as an animal stung by a tranquilizer dart.  She tak some irregular breaths waiting for normal life to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom the last person remaining in the room.  He approaches she is totally unaware of his presence, even when he casu mounts the stage with an athletic leap.  It takes courage Tom to fully intrude himself, which he now does:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Earnest, nervous -- handsome...Just when she needed a mir there it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to tell you  how great  you were.  My name's Tom Grunick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dumbly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hated me.  I don't hate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they say if you can reach even one person, it means something... And you did that. Jane looks up at his smile -- a beat then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to have dinner with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane arrives at the maitre d' stand.  She has attempted t up to the extent that  packing for a short-day trip allow looks for Tom.  Tom rises from a table and is immediately her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  I was worried I was early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a lot earlier. They are lead to a table and sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kept thinking what a great break it was for me to get to see you tonight.  More than a great break, maybe just what I needed...just when I needed it...Angel of mercy -- godsend...lifesaver...what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like "godsend."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't been in news that long. I've just been looking for the right person to talk to.  I have about two thousand questions for you. He notices that her head has gone into her hands where it continues to rest.  He looks at her a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible now's not the right time. She lifts her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we could just eat first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Totally understood.  Totally wrong of me to talk shop after the day you've had.  Totally sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooo.  If I could just have a roll, I'd be okay. She takes a roll from the roll plate.  He smiles at her. takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk along -- dumping occasionally and self-consc Jane is feeling a version of being turned on -- that is, adrift and temporarily free of obligations.  She is open making a memorable mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another thing I can't stand -- Is this dull? Tom shakes his head almost violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no... Jane looks at him curiously -- then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (broadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another thing I can't stand is ...when White House reporters bullshit with each other after a briefing and then one of them has a theory and the other quotes it in his story as "White House" sources say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That actually goes on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  My room is down here -- I'm not tired.  Do you want to keep talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small good room -- her working paraphernalia very much evidence...the quality briefcase...the reams of well orga notes...the thick contact book -- Jane is sitting on the Tom, not far away in the room's only chair.  One lamp is and it serves to place Jane in the shadows and cast Tom i enormously flattering light.  MUSIC comes from her miniat portable STEREO system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on...Even I'm not that hard on myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I really got this job on a fluke and wait till you hear where it ends up. Jane smiles a calming smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was doing sports at the station. The newspaper ran this untrue story that I was leaving and they got all these tons of protest mail.  So they made me anchor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So great -- right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except I'm no good at what I'm being a success at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you at back rubs? Jane shifts her position so that her back is to Tom... He immobilized by the sudden turn.  Jane waits, just a bit l than it would take a man to run from the chair to her sid experiencing the ghost-like clutch of rejection.  She mov briskly past the moment -- grabbing a "good night" chocol from the pillow and munching it as she return to his agen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sort of normal -- the way you feel.  In graduate school everyone thought the only mistake the admission committee made was letting them in. He moves to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me.  You keep on thinking I'm somebody ho lacks...confidence. That's not it.  I know I can talk well enough and I'm not bad at making contact with people, but I don't like the  feeling that I'm pretending to be a  reporter. (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And half the time I don't really get  the news I'm talking about.  It isn't that I'm down on myself.  Trust me, I stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (levelly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even have the chance to get really good at sports.  I wasn't bad. I thought I was starting to do interesting features but hockey is big at the station and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the obvious remedy? Reversing things.  Maybe getting a job on a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't write. Jane laughs or, more accurately, scoffs as Tom Continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that didn't stop me from sending out audition tapes to bigger stations and the networks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on -- it is your life. Nobody is tying you to the fast track.  Did you go to college?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One year...almost one year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're not well educated and you have almost no experience and you can't write. He nods agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm making a fortune. Jane laughs very briefly -- then rubs her face vigorously her hands... He's making her feel a little crazy.  She ge the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard for me to advise you since you personify something that I truly think is dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding it in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree with you -- you're not qualified. (letting it out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So get qualified.  You can insist on being better prepared.  You don't have to just leave it as... (mimicking him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'I don't write.  I'm not schooled. I don't understand the news I'm reading. But at least I'm upset about it, folks.' A beat, then he mumbles softly to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, this was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what do you want from me, anyway? Permission to be a fake?  Stop whining and do something about it. He gets up to leave.  She follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you don't have to start right now. He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated the way you talked to me just now...and it wasn't just because you were right. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It wasn't just the speech -- the same thing happened with this guy.  I have passed some line some place.  I am beginning to repel people I'm trying to seduce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he talks with Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agreeably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have been great-looking, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because nobody invites a bad- looking idiot to their bedroom. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Let's do me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I feel like I'm slipping but do people who are actually slipping feel that way or is it always the really good people who are moving up who invariably think they're slipping because their standards are so high?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This conversation is not worthy of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd give anything if that were true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't this be a great world if insecurity and desperation made us more attractive?  If needy were a turn-on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call if you get weird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up -- pulls back the bedspread on the double be on the other half are papers, schedules -- tapes.  She do clear them off so that she is literally sleeping with her The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking it was the shortest phone conversation we ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deserted well-lit area.  Tom on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never told you the reason I was telling you everything for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly surprised it's him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those audition tapes I sent out... I've been hired by your network for the Washington bureau.  So I'll probably see you at work.  Sorry. Jane is rocked and soured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane and Aaron walking to work -- agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't hire Peter Stiller from the Times and he had a great audition tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to start going over who they could have gotten?  They can't take on people like this for network news.  For God's sake.  What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom arrives for first day of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ERNIE MERRIMAN is the network's Washington Bureau Chief. is in his early 60's, has worked for the network about 40 -- part of the golden age -- a family man, an honorable m a good guy.  Right now he is welcoming Tom to the network thereby good-naturedly helping with the destruction of al holds dear.  As he hands Tom his credentials:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any particular area you feel strongest in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be honest, I was best at anchor. Ernie gives him a long look -- is he kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take a few days observing the system?  Then we'll put you on general assignment.

dialogues.speaker: EDITING ROOM
dialogues.text: Two small TV monitors -- a smallish room.  Jane goes over timing notes which correspond to the time code SUPERED on monitors.  BOBBIE -- an extraordinarily silent man -- is Jane's bidding.  On the monitor we SEE the mercenary piec which Jane is editing against a tightening deadline.  The PHONE RINGS periodically -- Jane conducting abrupt conver which continuing to edit.  The pressure is palpable to be with but builds and builds; almost like a family fight ge out of hand and threatening to bend lives.  Through it al remains remarkable calm.  Her focus is amazing; her comma

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting notes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to 316, Bobbie.  The sound bite in the cab -- it starts, 'I don't know how I'll feel...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Bobbie, we're pushing. As Bobbie expertly reverses the tape, Tom's face appears the glass doorway and then he enters the already crowded Jane's eyes click to him briefly.  She makes not a move t welcome him.  He pauses, but is committed and tries to fi a piece for himself against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said I should observe the... Jane is distracted by the noise... Tom leaning over towar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said it would be okay if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're working here!!  You can stand over in the uh, uh, uh... She momentarily can't think of the word 'corner.'  Then b to Bobbie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Play back the last line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said something about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me hear it! Bobbie, taking the sharp commands with ever increasing, yet still repressed resentment. The Assistant Director, BLAIR LITTON, enters the editing She is about 26 and every night since she got her job as Assistant Director she has been the first to crack under

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll need it in ten minutes.  We're putting it directly into... Jane holds up a finger of warning to Blair as she picks u ringing phone and talks to Bobbie at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig, just a second -- (to Bobbie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me hear it! Through much of this chaos we focus on:

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Wedged into an uncomfortable position between two tape ra He is wide-eyed at this circus of tension and fear.  His dart around constantly -- trying to take in as much as he always returning with wonder to focus on Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long time since I've seen my folks and all but...I don't expect any big-deal homecoming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop there. (into phone she's been holding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to shoot a picture from a book I have in the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have time.  Not a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right down.  It's right tight. She crosses out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to tell Ernie...because there isn't enough time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there is. Blair leaves, as Jane gathers up her notes.  She charges leaving Tom awkwardly along with Bobbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Tom Grunick.  I started on General Assignment today. Bobbie stops the machine, turns in his chair and shakes h Then he smiles secretly and speaks his first full sentenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think she's going to make it. Tom exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron is having a theoretical discussion with Ernie and JENNIFER MACK, a correspondent in her early 40's, a pione beauties in news.  She is well-schooled, bred, trained an known... GEORGE WEIN, a black correspondent in his 40s, a MARTIN KLEIN, formerly with the Johnson administration -- State Department correspondent for the network.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what about this?  Here's a tough ethical one.  Would you tell a source that you loved them just to get some information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer didn't know there was an alternative. Jennifer laughs that laugh one always hopes beautiful wom will laugh when one says something funny.  Aaron smiles a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's one.  They allow us to have cameras at an execution in Florida. Do you broadcast tape of the guy  in the chair when they turn on the voltage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing like wrestling with a moral dilemma is there? Blair enters the scene, Tom trailing several feet behind, continuing to monitor the budding deadline crises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Ernie, we're several minutes to air and Jane's shooting an insert still for tonight's piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows how much time she has. Blair flashes a tortured smile -- panic is growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I just wanted you to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is she shooting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman Rockwell's 'Homecoming.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's nice... (walking away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll need some new lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane up against it now -- but still seemingly calm.  Tom watching, keeps on glancing at the clock fascinated, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Bobbie, just a two-second dissolve to the Rockwell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a two-second dissolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, we have three minutes... Why do you do this to me.  Is it because I won an award?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where Aaron is writing his last line on a folded over pie paper even as he gets ready to record.  He times it with stop watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman Rockwell's enduring portrait of a Homecoming  The return of a fighting man has always been one of the more moving ceremonies of war... Tearful women, proud men, excited children.  But J.D. Singer was right -- his homecoming was no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a minute and a half.  It's my responsibility to tell them we won't be ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh.  We're be ready. Blair glances frantically at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In 84 seconds?

dialogues.speaker: ON CLOCK
dialogues.text: Sweeping from 28 minutes to -- 84 seconds from deadline. walks in, Jane looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleven and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.  Back it, Bobbie -- Bobbie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying 'Oh, God..."  They are going to go to up and the screen will be black -- they're going to go to black because we're not there.  How about careers, huh?  How about careers?

dialogues.speaker: ON CLOCK
dialogues.text: 42 seconds away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to make it. Bobbie makes a small bobble -- Jane giving the merest evi of the strain, scratching her face repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unravelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops?!?  Whoops?!?  No, please... no, ooh, ahhh, ohhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, shit, shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're almost there, you can do it -- can do -- can do. And as the pitch reaches its zenith, 27 seconds left.  Bo hands the tape to Blair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blair hikes up her skirt and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our "chase scene" as Blair soars through the newsroom, le chair smoothly, smashing her leg against a table in full the adrenaline deadening the pain -- she arrives at a wai elevator -- uses a key dangling from her neck to unlock i nervously during the ride and now, in FULL EXTENDED FLIGH down the long corridor heading to the control room where arrives; slamming the tape into a technician's hand even introduced on the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron, Jane, the others looking at the end of the piece o air -- Tom in the b.g. as Blair enters -- relaxed, almost

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was a little nervous there for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on -- tell us another.

dialogues.speaker: ON MONITOR
dialogues.text: The end of the piece -- the Rockwell painting giving way mercenary's actual homecoming which matches the portrait. irony works nicely.  The network anchorman comes up for h BILL RORISH, 50 years old and able to flutter much younge He is able and experienced -- a reporter who has become a journalistic king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on monitor, smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill Rorish...Thank you...Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that smile.  Oh, that was good and oh my, Bill smiled -- he liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He loved it.  Big smile. He gives Jane a congratulatory sock in the shoulder which returns -- Tom in the b.g. of the SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't seen Bill smile like that in weeks. Ernie has walked a few steps to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie, you missed his close... He smiled. (mimicking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...Good night. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw the smile -- good piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go look at it again. They leave -- Aaron waving to Tom who stands in the b.g. others leave.  Tom approaches Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry if I was in the way.  It was totally impressive.  Great piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat formal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't.  Thanks.  How does it feel being here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm really here.  No kidding.  If you're through work now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Aaron and I go to Central America on Wednesday -- so I'm cramming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were incredible in there. I know how much I have to learn.  I'd really -- a lot -- appreciate it...if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Really a lot appreciate it...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You  make me nervous.  Anyway if I can pick your brain -- Jane grimaces at "pick your brain."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help you, sorry.  I'm not here to teach remedial reporting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it has nothing to do with the fact I left your room instead of staying  there? Jane looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please. (then, almost gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to understand something.  This isn't personal. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Aaron, Jane and their CREW march along with a CONTRA S in their own conversation.  Except for the DIN of TROPICA they seem almost like a cranky married couple on their wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't sleep.  They're giving me less and less air time.  They don't think I'm at all anchor material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we don't get to their camp soon, we won't be able to tape the supplies coming in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time Paul was sick they gave Connie the weekend news instead of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spend too much time -- much too much worrying about that crap... (suddenly reacting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh good. They have entered a clearing where supplies have been dro the Guerrillas already tearing apart boxes with army boot inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guerrilla soldier rubbing his shoeless foot.  A pair of sit alongside him.  Jane's Cameraman prepares to shoot, s Spanish, then English:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put on the boot. Jane rushes into the scene incensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!  We are not here to stage the news. Wait and see what he does. Then to the totally confused soldier. JANE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you do whatever you want.  It's your choice. By now there is a fair-sized cluster of armed men as well the news team staring at the guerrilla, who is at loss as what is expected.  He looks to Jane, who can offer no hel save her own determination not to interfere.  Finally he on the boot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cameraman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. He shoots the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, in shirt and tie, is on the phone.  This is a big da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll meet the crew there then. Could you give me that address again? Great.  Yes, it's good to finally be getting to work.  Okay that's 17204?  1-7-2-0-4.  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Tom gets directions from the CONCIERGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only ten minutes if you prefer to walk... (as he walks away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll look for you on the news tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom has a real sense of the moment -- of having arrived. strange bubble of pleasure rises to the surface as he wal to cover his first story.  He laughs out loud, loving his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane in the f.g. with her crew while Aaron talks in rapid to the GUERRILLA LEADERS. AARON (in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you guys kidding or do you really think you'll run into something...? I mean, do you feel that every time and it never happens?  Or is it the first time it felt that way and it's going to happen?... I mean, how bad can it be?... Are you nervous...? What's the chances on a scale of one to ten -- that we're going to be in a war within the next few hours?... Really? He starts to walk towards Jane -- one of the men he was talking with calling after him with an added thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, you speak English very well too. (to Jane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great news.  He says they've been engaging the Sandinistas pretty regularly and that he'd be really surprised if we didn't take fire  tonight. Jane reacts -- a flash of exhilaration.  Aaron is amazed attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at her. (to Jane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anything happens to me tell every woman I've ever dated I was talking about them at the end.  That way they'll have to reevaluate me. Jane laughs out loud, attracting the Guerrillas' attentio Aaron repeats his speech in Spanish.  The Guerrillas laug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron and Jane in line behind the Guerrillas.  They HEAR The head of the patrol gestures -- deploying his men.  Aa grabs Jane and heads for some cover to the left.  As they more SHOTS.  Jane in work mode.  As soon as they settle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Spanish accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much too dark.  Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: ON AARON BARELY DISCERNIBLE
dialogues.text: As they start taping he is breathless with the nervousnes the nearly gunfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first shots were fired not thirty seconds ago.  The Contras feel they must be outnumbered this is so small a unit:  that's a given.  Still they hold their ground despite the fact that their weapons have been acting up -- misfiring or jamming.  A new shipment of rifles is expected tomorrow -- all they got today were the shoes. There is the SOUND OF GUNFIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cameraman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. (to Aaron)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great line at the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you shoot their boots?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can cut back at the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the pan of the supplies boxes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe it?  I just risked my life for a network that tests my face with focus groups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, squashed in amidst a small mob of reporters... behin police line.  He HEARS a reporter next to him say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's coming out now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his crew)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say he's coming out now. A surge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Reporter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Tom checks his notes.

dialogues.speaker: TOM'S BLACK BOOK
dialogues.text: The same model we've seen Jane use.  A list of questions written in big color highlighted letters.  As he looks do to study them, everyone else moves suddenly off. TOM'S P.O.V. The mass of journalists and technicians shouting question "Will you dispatch troops?" after the Ambassador they've awaiting -- clumping on his limo and then being shaken by movement of the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: ON TOM
dialogues.text: Standing alone and forlorn as his crew trots back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (observing Tom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a lot of questions here.  I missed the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, it's okay.  I got a piece of his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is standing -- talking to her crew.  Others asleep in b.g. -- a drowsy, morning-after feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all packed and ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stuff in the dark is not good. Nobody wants news lit like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you just get packed? She waves him off -- then she walks several yards away, h a knapsack in her hand.  She takes off a brush and runs i through her hair -- opens a plastic case and takes out a toothbrush, brushes her teeth and rinses her mouth with w from her canteen.  She puts everything back in place, the about, sobs for several beats.  One of the Guerrillas hea sobbing and enters the scene -- he stands a respectful di away.  Jane finishes, notices him, makes a face by way of explanation, and exits the scene feeling measurably bette

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Washington Control Room.  Jennifer, Jane, Aaron, Blai watching the intro to the Central American piece.  Tom st the distant b.g.  There are over a dozen monitors -- incl one which is constantly on the anchor man, Bill Rorish.

dialogues.speaker: ON TELEVISION MONITORS
dialogues.text: Bill Rorish on camera -- an INSERT behind showing Aaron i blackness planted into a Central American map bordered by A separate monitor shows the INSERT alone. BILL (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fire fight along the Nicaraguan border...in one minute. The INSERT MOVES OUT AT US TO FILL THE SCREEN -- WE SEE A dim outline and HEAR him say: AARON (voice over; on camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first shots were fired not thirty seconds ago. The MUSICAL "EVENING NEWS" SIGNATURE COMES IN ever-so-bri The SCREEN GOES TO A COMMERCIAL -- as Blair screams enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great graphic, great graphic. Ernie ENTERS THE  SCENE... He kisses Jane in greeting -- Aaron on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finally got a piece in a few minutes early and I hear Bill loved it. Jennifer gives Jane a mock pat on the back. ERNIE (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have somebody downstairs who one of the clerks brought in and vouches for. He says he has something to say about gays getting promotions at State... It can't hurt to tape him.

dialogues.speaker: ON JANE
dialogues.text: As she feels Tom staring at her -- turns and notices him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I buy you dinner sometime soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got back -- I don't know which end is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. In the b.g. WE MAY HAVE NOTICED Bill Rorish on one monito picks up the phone at his anchor desk, during the commerc break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane!  Bill Rorish wants to speak to you at the break. (as she hands it to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard of him handing over compliments in the middle of the show. There is a stillness in the Control Room as Jane speaks t anchor man in New York who WE CAN VIEW on a monitor.

dialogues.speaker: ON MONITOR
dialogues.text: We see Bill Rorish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, darling, if it gets any better than that, I'm going to have to bring you up here to New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  I just wish you'd kept the first twenty seconds. Blair cringes at Jane's blunt reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the visual with the boots at the end was just perfect. Jane covers the mouthpiece and turns to Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, he loved the boots. Aaron reaches happily for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron should be hearing this so I have an extra witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you always want to give the  credit away, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't.  He happens to deserve the credit.  He's right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll speak to you soon We see Rorish over the monitor.  He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Aaron)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had to read over some new copy. We see on the monitor that this is not so.  It's a very e Aaron.  Tom breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the rescue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay if I watch you tape that interview downstairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. As he passes Jane he leans next to her and WE HEAR him WH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please laugh so they think I'm not dying inside but have so much style I just said something funny. Jane does her part enormously well -- laughing with amuse but her eyes blaze -- her friend has been needlessly humi Blair wants desperately to be inside Aaron's joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if still amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUDDY FELTON waits alone.  A CAMERA CREW watches him.  He well dressed, exceedingly nervous.  He summons the courag ask a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I see how I photograph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause for the interview they're going to use a screen and disguise me to protect my anonymity so could I see myself before that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. The Camerawoman punches a button and immediately Buddy's comes up on a standing monitor on the studio floor.  He's happy with the image -- but works at concealing his react gasping a bit of air -- trying to touch it.  Aaron enters Tom smiles a friendly smile which flusters Buddy momentar But again he almost manages to conceal his private rush. internal drama is such he invariably finds himself coveri fearful roomfuls of people will simultaneously guess his thoughts. Aaron directs him behind a screen and looks at his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mr. Buddy Felton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your full name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might as well ask you the questions on tape.  Is that all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You worked at one time as  Foreign Service Trainee in the State Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was there two years and was promoted on merit nine times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually rising to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Office Bimbo.  (curbing his amusement)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. Aaron is having a hard enough day,  He is visibly annoyed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying the fact that you're gay had something directly to do with your promotions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eventually rising to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G.S.  I don't know. (scratches his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know numbers. Tom laughs.  Aaron shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying the fact that you're gay had something directly to do with your promotions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the word gay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which would you prefer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ravenous homosexual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the tape, okay.  Forget it, Ellen.  Let's call security and get him out. As Aaron walks out -- Tom is momentarily fixed on the sig walking in small circles giving himself a talking to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (self flagellating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great time to act out, Buddy.  You won't be happy until you turn the whole world off. He notices Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not really going to call security are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I get out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dazzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked me into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom distracted -- his day has been a bit of a bummer.  Bu self conscious -- the proximity creating an almost unbear tension of romance and adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Guard on duty -- a BLACK WOMAN.  She sees Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're the gay guy.  I was just coming to find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Guard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walking.  Buddy in step with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? Tom turns.  Buddy talks rather quickly -- He cares very m about leaving Tom with the right impression.  The last wo of his speech he hadn't expected to say. BUDDY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for not shunning me and all. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really did have all that information but I thought I might just be being vindictive to get a little hunk of the ol' spotlight.  I know, horrible -- but I didn't do it, so okay?  And thanks again and would you like to have a drink -- at a regular bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure.  Okay. His heart racing, Buddy attempts casual matter-of-factnes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a regular bar around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom and Buddy on adjoining stools.  For Tom, the last wee been humbling, antagonistic.  He's enjoying Buddy who lis attentively and wholeheartedly endorses every word Tom sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been doing some morning show stuff, but mostly radio -- that doesn't bother me.  I'm in no rush for anything.  It's just the snotty attitude, even if I have it coming, it's still...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...I mean you didn't do anything special for me tonight.  You just had what I think are good manners, decency. And it really makes me want to be nice back and it has nothing to do with any homosexual thing. (looks right at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly. (then away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I don't know if you've homosexual or not and -- you're not, are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One's enough. Tom signals for the check. BUDDY (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't doing anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  At least let me show my appreciation.  The Secretary of Labor is going to be indicted on Wednesday. For the graft thing he supposedly did before he was appointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's true.  They're going to make it public Wednesday but isn't it a big deal for you to have it a day and a half early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My roommate's very social -- somebody from Justice was over and...I always hear things before they happen.  Hey, and from now on, so do you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Weln, the black correspondent and Tom are seated i office with Ernie -- they are in mid-meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm virtually certain it's not true. He may be indicted eventually, but I don't think it will be this month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to be alone with me -- tell me your source?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told you I'm not sure it would  totally convince you, but I totally  believe the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insufferable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Labor is my Department -- I can't conform it and my contacts go very deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if it's true -- I'm terrific, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even a close call.  Of course we can't go with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane is working with Bobbie the editor... Snatches of the make it obvious that the Labor Secretary has been indicte George Weln stands behind Jane, who is dialing a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want him all the way to the  car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No stop where he's all besieged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bobbie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there, Bobbie. Tom enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he was indicted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were right not to go with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I was right -- just somebody give it to me.  I had a good story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to George)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to him -- so we can concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I don't want any credit.  Bobbie and I serve anonymously. He pats Bobbie on the back... and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing in his work)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I like Tom, because hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobbie, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded rush hour... Buddy and Tom stand next to each oth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the White House is hoping to keep a lid on it for a few days till they figure out what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, Buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brushing it off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please.  So they were really impressed with you at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not impressed exactly -- but a break in the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the change in you -- I see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 10 A.M. briefing just breaking up -- Jennifer leaves network seat in the front row, only to be grabbed by Tom steers her outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the near distance a circular driveway and a silent arm MARINE GUARD, standing at attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jennifer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he bought this Peugeot sedan at a greatly reduced price while he was there in charge of the White House Advance Team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're not chasing it down yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm junior man -- and it's your beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, that's nice...I wish we could all deal with each other like this. I'll check it.  Anything I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my first time at the White House. Is there any chance to look at where he works and the rest of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't have the guts to ask when I first came up.  I'll get you a great tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buddy and Tom watching the Evening News as Jennifer finis her story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over; on TV set)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President says it's not a violation but nonetheless White House sources say the full price will be paid for the Peugeot and new rules will put future bargain hunting off limits for Presidential Aides.  This is Jennifer Mack at the White House. Tom and Buddy smile at each other... energized -- up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, but it really is intoxicating being a news source.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody else had it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish it were you giving the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if we just don't tell them anything anymore unless they let you do the story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Really...don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  And look, in the future I can call you when I have news for you. Don't feel you have to spend time with me just to get the information. (a breath; then to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that wasn't as hard to say as you thought, was it, Buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  You're one of the few people in this town I can talk to. Buddy puts his hand to his heart and makes a LOUD SOUND O RAPTURE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoooo. The BARTENDER and some nearby patrons turn and look.  Tom with discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Buddy, don't do that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane waiting for an elevator... It comes and she steps on as Tom clearly excited comes around the bend from Ernie's calling for her.  He goes to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs out and sees Jane in the lobby below, then takes after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters and runs outside, looking in both directions running off to the right.  A BEAT -- REVEALING Jane has s to talk with Blair -- now she exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom on the street, ahead of her, thinking he's behind her He runs another half a block and stops dejected... Turns back to the office.  He keeps looking back to see if he m her, so that his head is turned as Jane reaches him, says fairly social:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, how are you? She keeps moving -- Tom spinning after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- I need you. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got another story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some public official skipped a week on his Christmas Club?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The House Armed Service Committee has a secret report which says that the General Stillwell tank the Army has dumped a fortune into plain  won't work.  I have it cold, confirmed.  They have five million dollars in this thing already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, billion...right, of course. They told me I could have any producer I wanted -- and I want you. As Tom savors the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various bureau personnel standing at their desks watching piece being broadcast.  We SEE a TANK MISFIRING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One source referred to it as a five billion dollar metal sculpture to ugly to look at and too big to bury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You write this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I write for you sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not because you have to.

dialogues.speaker: ON MONITOR
dialogues.text: We SEE a General walking away from Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Elton McGuire is in charge of the weapon system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been in the Army twenty-seven years -- so I'll let the Army ask the questions, not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, I don't want to bother you anymore or your family.  But tomorrow there will be a mob of me back here -- so, if you have anything to say, why not say it now, sir, the way you want?

dialogues.speaker: ON TOM
dialogues.text: He is a study. Looking at himself -- and though it's far from his first television -- it's the first time he's seen himself doing work and, by all appearances, doing it well.  As the Gene answers in the b.g. --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's great of us to have left in what you said -- just great of us. Tom smiles modestly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's never forget.  We're the real story.  Not them. Tom and Jane look over -- then Tom looks to Jane for a ve In the b.g., the news goes to a commercial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, I went back and forth on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I liked it.  He's not afraid to be human. Ernie ENTERS THE SCENE with his fourteen-year-old DAUGHTE in tow... He approaches Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My youngest wanted to meet you. This is Ellie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Ellie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be honored -- she never cares about meeting anyone here.  But she liked you on television just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering scene)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Ellie -- remember me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry -- from where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been to your house a lot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Aaron went on that fourteen day raft trip with us last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad...Did you see it?  Great -- I'll send you a tape...I'm sorry I haven't called.  Things were a little bumpy for a while.  It's not important... I'm fine now. (what he's been wanting to say aloud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad -- I just may be able to do this job...Well, I'm glad you were sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie is hosting the news staff for Sunday brunch -- they around drinking in small groups... Aaron is standing with and a MAN in his fifties we have not seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why we have to feel defensive about it.  Newspapers are in business to make money -- why not us? Aaron looks at her in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They criticize us for supposedly pandering while they run WINGO Games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly right.  Excuse me.  I'm paid to mix. Blair and Aaron laugh appreciatively as he walks off to a group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care, Paul. (back to Blair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
